config.question: Why did the yeomen farmers, who disdained “cotton snobs” and rich planters, fail to respond to antislavery appeals?

choices.content: The farmers received financial incentives from the planters to fight abolitionism.
The yeomen farmers did not want non-slaveholders to get ahead of them.
The abolitionist movement failed to reach the areas where smaller farmers lived.
The oppression of the blacks made the farmers feel powerful as a race.

answer_3.response: Consider This: Some non-slaveholders hoped to get ahead, and in the South, this meant acquiring slaves. Just enough more prosperous yeomen broke into the slaveholding classes to make this dream seem believable. Planters, anxious to ensure the loyalty of non-slaveholders, encouraged the notion that every white man was a potential master. See L.O. 11.2 What divided and united white southern society?
